head.title: National News Briefs; Harvard Names Curator For Journalism Program

hedline.hl1: National News Briefs; Harvard Names Curator For Journalism Program

abstract.p: Robert H Giles, longtime newspaper editor and publisher, will be next curator of Harvard University's Nieman Foundation for professional journalists (S)

block.p: Robert H. Giles, a longtime newspaper editor and publisher, will be the next curator of Harvard University's Nieman Foundation for professional journalists.

Friends of Mr. Giles confirmed yesterday that Harvard's president, Neil L. Rudenstine, had told Mr. Giles last week of the appointment to head the 62-year-old Nieman program, which brings 24 United States and foreign journalists to the university for a year's study. The appointment was first reported yesterday by Editor & Publisher magazine.
Robert H. Giles, a longtime newspaper editor and publisher, will be the next curator of Harvard University's Nieman Foundation for professional journalists.

Friends of Mr. Giles confirmed yesterday that Harvard's president, Neil L. Rudenstine, had told Mr. Giles last week of the appointment to head the 62-year-old Nieman program, which brings 24 United States and foreign journalists to the university for a year's study. The appointment was first reported yesterday by Editor & Publisher magazine.
Mr. Giles declined to comment, and the university said it would make an announcement on Tuesday.
Unions had challenged the candidacy of Mr. Giles, who earned the enmity of strikers when he was editor of The Detroit News.

Mr. Giles will replace Bill Kovach, who has been curator for the last decade. He is the second journalist named this summer to a highly visible academic post. In June, James R. Bettinger, a former city editor at The San Jose Mercury-News, was named director of Stanford University's Knight Fellowship Program.
